caseTitle: EDMUND ASANTE – APPIAH v MADAM KATE AMPONSAH ALIAS YAA MANSA
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana decision arose from a property dispute where the appellant, Edmund Asante-Appiah, claimed sole ownership of a house and plot in Apedwa purchased from the United African Company (UAC). The respondent, Madam Kate Amponsah (alias Yaa Mansah), widow of the appellant's half-brother, contested this, asserting joint ownership. The High Court initially ruled for the appellant, but the Court of Appeal reversed it. The Supreme Court dismissed the appellant's appeal, holding that the power of attorney used by the appellant—residing in England—was invalid under the Power of Attorney Act, 1998 (Act 548), as it lacked a witness signature per s.1(2). Consequently, the agent lacked capacity to litigate or testify. The appellant failed to present any documentary evidence (e.g., receipt, certificate of purchase) to prove the alleged purchase from UAC, a reputable colonial-era company, making an oral sale unenforceable under the Conveyancing Act, 1975 (NRCD 175), s.2. The Court affirmed the onus was on the appellant to prove title, which he failed to do, and that the respondent, having no counterclaim, bore no burden. The appeal was dismissed for lack of merit.
citations: Juxon-Smith v KLM Dutch Airlines [2005-2006] SCGLR 438
Edward Nassar & Co Ltd v McVroom [1996-97] SCGLR 468
Ebusuapanin Yaa Kwesi v. Arhin Davis (2006) 2 GMLR50
rationaleHighlights: Invalid power of attorney due to lack of witness signature under Act 548, s.1(2)
Appellant failed to prove title through documentary evidence as required by Conveyancing Act, NRCD 175, s.2
Onus of proof correctly placed on appellant as plaintiff claiming possession and injunction
Oral admissions insufficient to establish title for property originally owned by UAC
Pleadings alone cannot constitute evidence; appellant's case reduced to inadmissible pleadings
